title: 105_hr633
content: The Department of State Special Agents Retirement Act of 1998 establishes retirement benefits for special agents of the Department of State with a primary skill code of 2501. The curr_chunk states that the activities include investigating, apprehending, or detaining individuals suspected or convicted of criminal offenses in the United States, as well as protecting individuals from threats to personal safety. The curr_chunk amends the requirements for employment opportunities in activities related to investigating, apprehending, or detaining individuals suspected or convicted of criminal offenses in the United States. It limits employment to young and physically vigorous individuals, allows for transfer to supervisory or administrative positions after 3 years of service, and includes conforming amendments to the Act. The curr_chunk adds definitions and amendments related to special agents and contributions under the Act. The curr_chunk introduces amendments regarding the computation of annuities for special agents under the Act, specifying the application of percentages of basic pay from title 5, United States Code. The curr_chunk specifies the percentages of basic pay from title 5, United States Code for special agents retiring under specific conditions. The curr_chunk outlines the eligibility criteria for special agents to receive annuity payments after completing at least 20 years of service. It also includes provisions for special agents with prior service under different retirement systems. The curr_chunk details the amendment to paragraph (7) for special agents under subchapter II, allowing credit for service as a special agent, law enforcement officer, or Capitol Police member towards annuity payments. The curr_chunk discusses technical and conforming amendments related to retirement systems under the Foreign Service Act. SEC. 3. MANDATORY SEPARATION OF SPECIAL AGENTS. The Foreign Service Act of 1980 is amended to mandate the separation of certain individuals from the Service upon reaching 57 years of age or completing 20 years of service. The Foreign Service Act of 1980 is amended to require the separation of individuals from the Service at age 57 or after 20 years of service. Effective date and applicability are specified in Section 4. The Act and its amendments will take effect upon enactment and apply to new special agents and those making an election under subsection (b). Current participants under chapter 8 of the Foreign Service Act of 1980 can make an election if they are serving or have served as a special agent, or if they are a survivor of a special agent eligible to make an election. If an individual makes an election under this section, the amendments made by this Act will apply to them, and they can make a special contribution for prior service. The Foreign Service Act of 1980 (as amended) includes provisions on interest computation and actuarial reduction. If the full special contribution is paid, no reduction applies. If less than the full amount is paid, the annuity will be reduced to cover the actuarial present value of the shortfall. The Secretary of State must promulgate regulations and provide notice to participants within 6 months of the Act's enactment. An election under the Act must be made within 90 days of receiving notice. The term "special agent" is defined as per the Foreign Service Act of 1980.
